ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Presence of multiple tumors (CPA and parietal lobe) in a young patient without family history; confirmed by subsequent development of contralateral tumor.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Vestibular Schwannoma (Acoustic Neuroma)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Large 4-5 cm mass in the right CPA causing retrocochlear audiometric signs (poor speech recognition, absent reflexes, abnormal ABR).

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Meningioma
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: The second tumor found in the superior parietal lobe was thought to be a meningioma.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing sensitivity and configuration given the complaint of hearing loss.
To evaluate speech understanding and check for retrocochlear signs like disproportionately poor scores.
To test the reflex arc; absence or decay can indicate retrocochlear pathology.
To assess neural integrity and screen for retrocochlear lesions.
To visualize the CPA and brain structures due to retrocochlear indicators.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The patient presents with right-sided sensorineural hearing loss with a distinct notch at 2000 Hz. Speech recognition is disproportionately poor (14%), strongly suggesting retrocochlear pathology. This is supported by absent acoustic reflexes on the right and an abnormal ABR (poor Wave V on the right, extended Wave V on the left suggesting brainstem compression). MRI confirms a large right CPA mass and a second parietal lobe mass, leading to a diagnosis of Neurofibromatosis.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Left ear normal. Right ear sensorineural loss with a sharp dip to ~80 dB HL at 2000 Hz, rising to normal at 6000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Left ear 100%. Right ear 14% at 50 dB SL, which is disproportionately poor relative to the pure tone thresholds.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Normal for left ear stimulation. Absent for right ear stimulation (ipsilateral and contralateral) at 500-4000 Hz.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Readable Wave I, poorly defined/questionable Wave V at ~7.4 msec. Left ear: Normal I-IV, Wave V extended (6.12 msec). Wave I amplitude larger than IV-V complex bilaterally.

tests.name: MRI
tests.result_summary: 4-5 cm mass in the right CPA compressing the brainstem; second mass in the superior parietal lobe.

proposed_items: Surgical removal of the CPA and parietal lobe tumors
counseling_actions: Explain the discrepancy between pure tone thresholds and poor speech recognition as a sign of nerve involvement
Discuss MRI findings showing the CPA mass and secondary brain mass
Discuss the diagnosis of Neurofibromatosis and the need for genetic counseling despite lack of family history
Prepare the patient for the likelihood of total hearing loss in the right ear following surgery

escalation.rationale_short: Large CPA tumor compressing the brainstem and a second intracranial tumor requiring immediate surgical intervention.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor for recurrence, management of NF2, and surveillance of the remaining hearing ear.

expected_outcome: Patient underwent surgery for removal of the CPA and parietal lobe tumors.
Subsequently developed an acoustic tumor on the other side as well as other CNS tumors.
